childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1994-2006

The year 1994 brought O.J. Simpson leading police on a slow-speed chase in a white Ford Bronco, 95 million Americans watching live—more than watched that year's Super Bowl. Somewhere between the real-time car chase and the courtroom drama that followed, America discovered it could not look away from spectacle. This would define the media landscape of this generation's entire life.

The first year coincided with the Rwandan genocide—800,000 people killed in 100 days while the world mostly watched. Nelson Mandela became South Africa's first Black president, ending apartheid. Kurt Cobain died in April. The World Wide Web was being born in research labs and garages, but parents were still using phone books and encyclopedias. Amazon was founded that July in a garage.

Google launched when this cohort was four, Columbine happened when they were six, 9/11 when they were seven. These weren't news stories they'd read about later—they were the texture of their childhood, events that happened while they were learning to read and ride bikes. Growing up in the shadow of that September morning, watching adults process shock and fear they'd never expected, learning that the world was fragile in ways nobody had warned them about.

This cohort was the last to have an analog early childhood and a digital adolescence. Probably remembering VHS tapes and Saturday morning cartoons before streaming existed. Having a CD player before an iPod. Calling friends on landlines, memorizing their numbers, enduring dial-up internet sounds, and learning to type on a keyboard before ever touching a touchscreen. Then everything accelerated.

YouTube existed by the time this cohort was twelve. The iPhone had launched by fourteen. This cohort didn't grow up with social media—they watched it colonize their life in real-time, platform by platform. MySpace came first, teaching HTML through profile customization. Then Facebook, then everything else. Among the first generation of teenagers to document every awkward moment online, not knowing it would follow them forever.

generational_identity.html:
The Millennial Generation

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996—and this cohort is near the tail end, which means they share some DNA with older Gen Z. Pew Research draws the line at 1996, so they made the cut by two years. Some researchers call this micro-generation 'Zillennials'—old enough to remember life before smartphones, young enough to have grown up on social media.

This generation numbers roughly 72 million people in the US, making it the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. This generation grew up being told they were special, that they could be anything, that participation trophies meant everyone was a winner. Then they graduated into a crater and found out the trophies were participation, not victory.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. This cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. Old enough to remember it clearly, young enough that it shaped their entire worldview rather than disrupting an existing one. They don't remember a pre-9/11 America with much clarity. Airport security, forever wars, surveillance culture—that's just how things were.

This generation graduated into the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. This cohort was fourteen when Lehman Brothers collapsed, which meant they watched parents' retirement accounts evaporate, watched neighbors lose homes, learned viscerally that financial security was fiction. By the time they entered the job market around 2016, the damage was embedded. Entry-level positions required five years of experience. Internships were unpaid. The gig economy wasn't liberation—it was the only option left.

This generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. This generation has been blamed for killing everything from casual dining to the diamond industry. The joke got old around the time they realized they couldn't afford rent, let alone diamonds. Millennials are sandwiched between Gen X (who got theirs before the economy collapsed) and Gen Z (who never expected to get anything in the first place). Optimistic enough to believe things could get better, cynical enough to know they probably won't.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1994 brought Forrest Gump winning Best Picture and The Lion King teaching every kid in America that death was inevitable, father figures could be murdered by their brothers, and Elton John would be there to sing about it. Pulp Fiction came out, but this cohort was too young to appreciate Tarantino's non-linear storytelling until they watched it at a sleepover a decade later and felt sophisticated.

Musically, 1994 was the year grunge peaked and died. Kurt Cobain's suicide in April made him a martyr and ended an era. Weezer released their Blue Album—irony and sincerity mixed in ways this generation would perfect. Green Day's Dookie went diamond and brought punk to the suburbs. Boyz II Men were everywhere. TLC warned about chasing waterfalls. The Notorious B.I.G. dropped Ready to Die. It was a strangely excellent year for music—an inflection point between decades.

TV in 1994 gave the world Friends, which would define sitcom aesthetics for the next decade and make everyone believe they could afford a massive Manhattan apartment on a barista's salary. ER launched the same night, making medical dramas appointment viewing. Ellen premiered. My So-Called Life lasted one perfect season before cancellation. The Simpsons was at its absolute peak.

This childhood was peak Nickelodeon—Rugrats, Hey Arnold!, All That, the orange VHS tapes. Catching the tail end of the Disney Renaissance and the beginning of Pixar's dominance. Adolescence belonged to MySpace profiles with auto-playing songs that announced emotional states, emo music, and the endless debate about Fall Out Boy versus Panic! at the Disco.

The first iPhone launched when this cohort was thirteen, which means they got a smartphone during their most formative social years. High school experience was documented on Facebook. College years were filtered through Instagram. The culture consumed wasn't broadcast at them—it was something they participated in, remixed, and shared. That shift happened while they were watching.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1994 brought Netscape Navigator launching, making the World Wide Web accessible to regular people for the first time. Marc Andreessen was twenty-three and had just built the browser that would start the dot-com boom and eventually consume the world. The internet was moving from research labs to living rooms, though family computers probably ran Windows 3.1 and couldn't go online at all yet.

Sony released the PlayStation in Japan this birth year—a console that would define gaming for this generation and prove that CD-ROMs were the future. Amazon was a bookstore operating out of Jeff Bezos's garage, which in retrospect was like watching a small fire that would eventually burn down everything.

Google launched when this cohort was four. The dot-com bubble burst when they were six, teaching adults that internet companies needed revenue, not just ideas. 9/11 happened when they were seven, which accelerated surveillance technology and security theater. Facebook opened to high schools when they were ten. The first iPhone arrived when they were twelve. This cohort watched the smartphone revolution happen during their most formative years.

This makes them one of the last people to remember life before the internet was everywhere. They know what boredom felt like before screens could fill every empty moment. They remember printing MapQuest directions, going to Blockbuster, waiting a week to see photos they'd taken. Fluent in both analog and digital, which is increasingly rare.

This generation's relationship with technology is intimate and complicated. Native to social media in ways older Millennials aren't, but remembering life before it in ways Gen Z doesn't. Can troubleshoot parents' Wi-Fi and explain memes to confused aunts. Translators between generations, fluent in both languages, belonging fully to neither.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Nelson Mandela was inaugurated as South Africa's first Black president two months after this cohort's birth, ending apartheid. The Rwandan genocide happened that same year—800,000 people murdered in 100 days while the world watched and mostly did nothing. This birth year contained both historic hope and historic horror.

The Oklahoma City bombing killed 168 people when this cohort was three, including children in a daycare. It was domestic terrorism before anyone used that phrase commonly. Princess Diana died when they were five, and they probably don't remember it clearly, but they remember adults being upset, the endless funeral coverage, the collective grief performed on television.

This cohort was seven during 9/11. Second grade. Remembering being sent home from school, or watching the towers fall on classroom TV, or coming home to parents who looked afraid in ways they'd never seen. Everything after divided into before and after. The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq started soon after. This generation has never known an America not at war somewhere.

Hurricane Katrina happened when this cohort was ten, watching a major American city drown while the government fumbled the response. The financial crisis hit when they were fourteen—old enough to understand something was wrong, that parents were worried, that the economy had broken. Obama was elected when they were fourteen—the first Black president, 'hope and change' as a slogan before it became ironic.

Sandy Hook happened when this cohort was nineteen. Same-sex marriage became legal nationwide when they were twenty-two. Trump announced his campaign when they were twenty-two. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world. This generation has lived through more destabilizing events by thirty than their grandparents experienced in entire lifetimes.

The through-line is disruption. Every time stability seemed possible, something shattered it. This generation has learned to expect crisis, to treat chaos as the baseline. This isn't pessimism—it's pattern recognition based on lived experience.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

College graduation around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, depending on education path. The 2008 financial crisis happened when this cohort was fourteen—they watched older siblings and cousins struggle to find jobs, learned early that a college degree wasn't the golden ticket previous generations promised. By the time they graduated, the economy had technically recovered, but wages hadn't, and neither had expectations.

This generation perfected the 'side hustle' because one job doesn't cover rent, let alone student loans. Probably driving for Uber, delivering for DoorDash, selling things on Etsy, or monetizing some skill on Fiverr. The gig economy isn't liberation—it's filling gaps that full-time employment used to cover. Becoming entrepreneurial by necessity, not choice.

Working in offices with ping-pong tables and cold brew on tap, performative perks masking the fact that they're salary-exempt and expected to answer Slack at midnight. Going through rounds of layoffs, watching companies announce record profits while cutting headcount, learning that 'we're a family here' means 'we'll exploit loyalty until quarterly earnings require otherwise.'

Remote work became normalized because of COVID, which hit when this cohort was in their mid-twenties—early career, still establishing themselves. Barely figuring out how offices worked before everyone went remote. Learning to build a career through screens, which is great preparation for whatever comes next but terrible for learning the informal skills that physical presence teaches.

This cohort is in the early-to-mid stages of their career now. Earning potential is theoretically ahead of them, but so is uncertainty. Climate change, AI disruption, political instability—the future their career needs to navigate doesn't look like any future previous generations planned for. Building on shifting sand.

Learning to list 'passion' on resumes because employers want them to care deeply about their mission while paying them barely enough to survive. Watching younger Gen Z colleagues set firmer boundaries and wondering why they didn't think to do that earlier. Senior enough now to mentor interns, junior enough to still feel expendable.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

This generation grew up with dating apps as default infrastructure. Tinder launched when they were eighteen—they didn't adapt to swipe culture, they came of age inside it. For them, meeting people online isn't weird or novel. It's just how things work. Parents find this baffling. Gen Z friends think any other method is inefficient.

Probably having at least one relationship that happened primarily through text messages and DMs. Knowing the anxiety of read receipts that confirm they saw a message and chose silence. Knowing the calculation of response timing—too fast seems desperate, too slow seems uninterested. Having fights via message that would have been resolved in sixty seconds face-to-face.

This generation delayed marriage longer than any before—not because they don't want partnerships, but because weddings cost the median American salary and they're still paying off student loans that were supposed to be investments. The life script parents followed—graduate, marry, house, kids by thirty—isn't available at a price anyone can afford. Improvising a new script.

Communication is asynchronous by default. Maintaining friendships through group chats and Instagram comments. Having relationships across time zones because everyone moves for work now. Knowing how to be close to people who are far away and distant from people who are near. The pandemic accelerated this—everyone learned what this generation already knew about building connection through screens.

Probably better at digital communication than face-to-face, which is both skill and handicap. Can craft the perfect text but fumble small talk. Going on dates that felt like job interviews because they're better at presenting a curated version of themselves than being spontaneous in real-time. Authenticity is harder when they've been performing online since middle school.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

The dot-com bubble burst when this cohort was ten—abstract at the time, but they absorbed the anxiety from adults. The 2008 financial crisis hit when they were fourteen, watching parents worry about jobs they'd thought were secure, watching neighbors lose homes they'd thought were theirs. The COVID economic collapse came when they were twenty-six. This generation has watched the economy implode three times before turning thirty-five. This has given them a financial worldview best described as 'expecting the floor to drop out at any moment.'

The relationship with money is defined by scarcity that started before they had any of their own. Probably graduating with student loan debt that will follow them for decades. Watching housing prices climb 40% in five years while wages grew 3%. The math doesn't work. Everyone knows the math doesn't work. Nothing changes.

Saving obsessively or not at all—there's rarely middle ground. Either paranoid about the next crash and hoarding cash, or deciding that since they'll never afford a house anyway, they might as well enjoy what they have now. Both responses make sense given the circumstances. Neither is particularly healthy long-term.

This generation has been lectured about lattes and avocado toast by people who bought houses for what they pay in annual rent. The generational wealth gap is the widest it's ever been, and they're on the wrong side. Boomers accumulated assets when they were cheap. This generation is accumulating debt while assets are expensive. The appreciation they received for existing and holding deeds—this generation will never see that.

This generation is redefining financial success because the old definitions don't apply to their circumstances. It's not homeownership—it's paying rent in a city they can't afford because that's where the jobs are. It's not retirement at 65—it's working until something breaks. It's not building wealth for their kids—it's hoping they won't become their financial burden. The goalposts moved while they were still running toward them.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's greatest weakness is the same as its greatest strength: they believe everything can be optimized. Tracking sleep, steps, calories, screen time, productivity scores. Approaching self-improvement like a productivity hack with quantifiable metrics. The problem is they can't gamify their way out of systemic collapse. Some problems don't have apps. Some failures aren't personal.

This generation is so good at adapting to broken systems that they sometimes forget to question whether the systems should exist at all. Normalizing precarity as a condition of adult life. Accepting that healthcare depends on employment, that education requires debt, that retirement might never happen. Learning to cope instead of demanding structural change.

This generation is conflict-averse in ways that cost them money and dignity. Raised on participation trophies and told to be team players and bring solutions not problems. Working unpaid overtime for 'experience.' Accepting 'equity' instead of salary because the CEO made it sound exciting. Enduring toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and they need health insurance. Trained to accommodate, and employers have noticed.

This generation is so steeped in irony that earnestness feels dangerous. They can't just like something—they have to like it ironically, or acknowledge its problematic elements while still enjoying it, or defend their enjoyment preemptively. This protective distance makes it hard to advocate for themselves without hedging. Their emotional armor is also their emotional cage.

This generation is so online that they sometimes mistake performance for action. Can mobilize hashtags faster than any generation before. But changing policy requires showing up to boring local meetings that don't generate engagement metrics. Can cancel people on Twitter and feel righteous. Structural change requires sustained, unglamorous work that nobody likes and shares.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2014-2024): Coming of age in a recovering economy that somehow never felt recovered—corporations posted profits while wages stagnated. Graduating into a job market that demanded experience they couldn't get without jobs that wouldn't hire them without experience. Probably living with roommates well into the late twenties, moving cities for work or cheaper rent, delaying everything parents did in their twenties. This was supposed to be the 'exploration' decade. It became the 'survival' decade. Making it work because they had to.

The 30s (2024-2034): Entering this decade now. Making more money than they did at twenty-five, but costs have outpaced income at every turn. Supposed to 'settle down,' but settlement requires capital they don't have. This is the decade where people traditionally buy houses, have kids, establish careers. Might do some of these things. Will probably do them later than parents did, on shakier financial ground, with less institutional support. The timeline stretched because the economics demanded it.

The 40s (2034-2044): This should be the peak earning decade, statistically. Probably having more authority at work, more clarity about what matters, more acceptance of what they can't change. Parents will be aging, which adds responsibilities and costs. If they have kids, they'll be teenagers—expensive, complicated, exhausting. Sandwiched between generations, managing everyone's needs while theirs wait. This is the decade where they either double down on the life they've built or realize it's not working and start over.

The 50s (2044-2054): By now, having lived through at least four economic crises, likely another pandemic, and countless 'unprecedented' events that happen every few years now. Retirement age keeps moving—it'll probably be seventy by then, if Social Security still exists. Mentoring people who don't remember a pre-smartphone world. Annoyed at how they take things for granted, and annoyed at themselves for becoming that person.

The 60s and beyond (2054+): Retirement won't look like parents' retirement—the leisure, the travel, the complete cessation of work. It'll be part-time work, gig economy hustle, or dependence on kids who are struggling themselves. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable from the one this generation grew up in. Telling younger people about life before smartphones, before the internet was everywhere, before AI was embedded in everything. They won't believe it. This generation will barely believe it themselves.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year. This cohort is part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials. On the younger end of the range, which means they share some characteristics with Gen Z while remaining distinctly Millennial in formative experiences.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): More educated, more diverse, and significantly poorer adjusted for age. Gen X entered the workforce when the economy functioned and rewarded participation. This generation entered after it broke. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing. Gen X got affordable college. This generation got crushing debt. Gen X got pensions. This generation got 401(k)s that crater every time the market gets nervous. Gen X got stability. This generation got 'disruption' and 'pivot.'

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were this age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. This generation controls 7%. Boomers bought houses for one or two years' salary. This generation is spending a year's salary on rent. Boomers had defined-benefit pensions and Social Security they'll collect for decades. This generation is hoping Social Security survives long enough for them to see any of it.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Similar but slightly more optimistic—or maybe just more naive. This generation remembers a time before everything felt broken, when the future seemed like it might work out. Gen Z doesn't have that memory. They arrived after hope left. This generation believed the system could be reformed. Gen Z is building alternatives because they've given up on reform. This generation adapted to smartphones in their teens; Gen Z was born holding them.

Life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations. This generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, measured by every available metric. More anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world they inherited is harder and lonelier than the one promised to them in those optimistic '90s.

But this generation is also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of injustice than any generation before. They've normalized therapy, destigmatized mental health struggles, pushed for equity their parents' generation didn't acknowledge. This generation inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. That matters, even when it doesn't feel like enough.

year_events: O.J. Simpson chase captivated 95 million viewers
Nelson Mandela elected South Africa's first Black president
Rwandan genocide killed 800,000 people in 100 days
Amazon founded in Jeff Bezos's garage
